text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in the Danish press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

--- U.S. morning tv-programme "Goodmorning America" is to broadcast from Copenhagen on May 12. The programme will report on brewer Carlsberg, porcelain group Royal Copenhagen, toymaker Lego and conduct interviews with well-known Danes before moving on to Stockholm, Oslo. Helsinki, and Reykjavik.

--- Denmark's fishing association wants the government to block all decisions from the European Union on fishing as long as other EU countries do not cut down their fishing fleets according to EU rules.
---Employers and shop and office workers' unions negotiating the first of this year's major pay deals are still far apart on a figure for wage increases.

--- Development minister Poul Nielson says that Denmark is to grant 60 million crowns as promised to Rwanda to help rebuild the country in spite the recent killing of foreign aid workers and severe criticism of the country's legal system.
---Mortgage lender Nykredit is to start offering bond-linked loans as a routine option.
---"Wise woman" Nina Smith says that welfare reform should begin now as it will be more painful if forced upon society later.
--- Culture minister Ebbe Lundgaard wants to convert partly state funded TV channel TV 2 into a private limited company in the course of 1997. REUTER
